chapter.title: Upgrading from Previous Releases
chapter.para: This chapter introduces steps to upgrade &storage; from the previous release to the current one.

sect1.title: General Upgrade Procedure
sect1.para: Before upgrading the &ceph; cluster itself, you need to add a new version of the &storage; product to the existing operating system, and update the software to the latest versions on each cluster node. You can upgrade daemons in your cluster while the cluster is online and in service. Certain types of daemons depend upon others. For example &ceph; &rgw;s depend upon &ceph; monitors and &ceph; OSD daemons. We recommend upgrading in this order:

tip.para: We recommend upgrading all the daemons of a specific type—for example all monitor daemons or all OSD daemons—one by one to ensure that they are all on the same release. We also recommend that you upgrade all the daemons in your cluster before you try to exercise new functionality in a release.
After all the daemons of a specific type are upgraded, check their status.
Ensure each monitor has rejoined the quorum after all monitors are upgraded:
Ensure each &ceph; OSD daemon has rejoined the cluster after all OSDs are upgraded:

step.screen: sudo zypper ref && sudo zypper patch

step.para: Install &storage; extension to which you are upgrading with &yast;SoftwareAdd-On ProductsAdd.
After the new product is added, refresh the installed software repositories.
Upgrade the installed software to the new version.
After the last &ceph; node is upgraded, check the cluster status.

sect1.title: Upgrade from &storage; 2.1 to 3
sect1.para: This section includes steps specific to upgrading &storage; version 2.1 to 3.

The basic procedure for upgrading from &storage; 2.1 to &storage; 3 is to install the ses-upgrade-helper package and run the upgrade-to-ses3.sh script as &rootuser; on each cluster node (except the admin node) in succession. This can be done while the cluster is running. The upgrade involves a number of caveats that are described below.

sect2.title: 'ceph' User and Group
sect2.para: As of &storage; 3, the &ceph; daemons (MON, OSD, MDS, RGW) newly run as the unprivileged user ceph. This is a major change from all previous versions, when all of the daemons (except RGW, which was a special case) ran as &rootuser;.

Since the ceph user will probably already be present on all your nodes, you need to either delete it or rename it to something else before installing &storage; 3. We recommend renaming it to cephadm on all nodes including the admin node. On the cluster nodes, the upgrade-to-ses3.sh script takes care of this for you. On the admin node, it can be done manually:

tip.para: The usermod -l command only renames the user and does nothing else. You will probably also need to set up a home directory for the &cephuser; user and modify the /etc/sudoers file using the visudo command.

sect2.para: During the product upgrade, a new ceph user and group are created with the default UID/GID 167 (if available). If UID/GID 167 are not available in your environment, the first available UID/GID will be used when creating the ceph user and group. Since this can complicate migration of OSD disks from one node to another, it is good practice to choose (and impose) a cluster-wide UID/GID for the ceph user and group. But this is only necessary if 167, the preferred UID/GID, is already used for some other user/group.

sect2.title: Change Ownership of /var/lib/ceph
sect2.para: The &ceph; daemons store their state in /var/lib/ceph. In &storage; version 1, 2 and 2.1 the daemons run as &rootuser;, and the /var/lib/ceph directory is owned by &rootuser;. Upgrading from any of these versions to &storage; 3 requires manually changing the ownership to ensure that the upgraded daemons can access this directory tree.
Before upgrading the &ceph; related packages, make sure that CEPH_AUTO_RESTART_ON_UPGRADE is set to "no" in /etc/sysconfig/ceph.

sect2.title: &rgw; Instance Name Change
sect2.para: In &storage; 2.1 and earlier, ceph-deploy prefixed &rgw; instance names with the string radosgw. and this prefix was hard-coded in the &rgw; &systemd; unit file.
As of &storage; 3, this prefix is no longer hard-coded in the unit file.

sect2.title: &rgw; Log File
sect2.para: In &storage; 2.1, each &rgw; instance has a section named [client.radosgw.instance_name] in /etc/ceph/ceph.conf, where instance_name is the name of your &rgw; instance. This section contains &rgw;-specific configuration parameters. One of these parameters is
In &storage; 3, &rgw; no longer logs to /var/log/ceph-radosgw. Instead, the log file with the same name is expected to be in /var/log/ceph along with the log files of the other &ceph; daemons.
The upgrade-to-ses3.sh script removes this line from /etc/ceph/ceph.conf if it is present. If you are upgrading manually, you will need to do this yourself.

After the upgrade, &rgw; instances will log to /var/log/ceph, along with the other &ceph; daemons. Their log files will be rotated by the standard &ceph; logrotate configuration file /etc/logrotate.d/ceph.

sect2.title: CRUSH Tunables
sect2.para: During the upgrade, you may see the cluster go into "HEALTH_WARN" state and complain about "legacy tunables". This is not dangerous, and can be rectified after the entire cluster is running &storage; 3.
If your cluster is still complaining about "legacy tunables" after all nodes have been upgraded, you have three options:

listitem.para: You can stay on legacy tunables and suppress the warning by adding the following option to your ceph.conf [mon] section:
listitem.screen: mon warn on legacy crush tunables = false
listitem.para: For the change to take effect, you will need to restart the monitors, or apply the option to running monitors with:
Adjusting the tunables will result in some data movement, which can affect cluster performance. Choose a time when the cluster is not under heavy load, and run:
listitem.screen: sudo ceph osd crush tunables firefly
listitem.para: Although the "firefly" tunables profile may not be the 'latest and greatest', some supported clients and kernels may not be able to work with the newer tunables.

warning.para: Note that this is not recommended or supported and you take such a step at your own risk.

listitem.para: If you are certain that all your clients and kernels support the latest tunables, you can migrate the cluster to them by running:
listitem.screen: sudo ceph osd crush tunables optimal

tip.para: Since adjusting CRUSH tunables can cause significant data movement within the cluster, consider doing it when the cluster's load is low.

sect2.title: Apache to Civetweb Migration
sect2.para: While &storage; 1.0 used Apache as an application server for &rgw; client/server communication, &storage; 2 introduced a new application server called Civetweb. Civetweb is a lightweight embedded Web server, which makes &rgw; configuration easier.
Although &rgw; in &storage; 2 still works well with Apache, support for Apache will end in future &storage; releases. You can migrate to Civetweb either manually, or using ceph-deploy.
